image.altText: A man sits at a kitchen table with an open laptop in front of him.

props.synopsis: NT home owners say lax residential building regulations have left them dealing with major structural defects they aren't able to get fixed or claim compensation for. They are calling on both sides of NT politics to commit to changing that.

title.children: Jonathan bought a defective new apartment and then found regulators can't do anything about it

image.altText: An exterior photo of Parliament House in Darwin. There are large palm trees out the front.

props.synopsis: As the NT election campaign kicks off, its first week has been marked by big spending promises and criticism of poor consultation over future policy.

title.children: Starter's gun fired on NT election campaign, with big money and policy change promises

image.altText: A woman with dark hair smiling and a man with blond hair and pursed lips

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris's campaign team says Donald Trump is trying to back out of a debate scheduled to run on a rival network.

title.children: Harris, Trump disagree on presidential debate as Trump proposes Fox News event

image.altText: Anthony Albanese gestures while speaking.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese sits down with Insiders to discuss his shift on Indigenous affairs on the second full day of the Garma festival. Follow live.

title.children: PM grilled on Indigenous issues at Garma as leaders look to the future

image.altText: A man picks through broken concrete in a destroyed multi-level building

props.synopsis: Hamas initiates a broad consultation process to select a new leader following the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh.

title.children: Hamas looks for new leader amid Israeli strikes in Gaza and West Bank

image.altText: Three different images of Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: Looking back over past Garma festivals, the prime minister appears to be presenting in a very different way than he did three years ago.

title.children: Three years, three Garma festivals, and three different versions of Anthony Albanese

image.altText: Pool (1)

props.synopsis: In 2020, three childcare workers took six children on their weekly excursion to the pool – but only five made it home. A five-day inquest has probed how one toddler was left behind at a public swimming pool.

title.children: Alone and locked in a public pool, Kumanjayi drowned in minutes. His family wants answers

image.altText: Vladimir Putin is embraced by a woman wearing a pale blue top. They're standing at the bottom of airplane stairs.

props.synopsis: Eight prisoners, whose crimes included murder, espionage, hacking and fraud, have returned to Russia in the largest prisoner swap between the West and Russia since the Cold War.

title.children: With a hug from Putin, a stark prediction came true as horrified victims watch on

image.altText: A close-up composite image of the two women who both have a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Territorians will head to the polls in three weeks for what's likely to be a close contest between the Labor government and the Country Liberal Party opposition. Here are the key players and big issues shaping the election.

title.children: Everything you need to know about the NT election

image.altText: a middle-aged male police officer in uniform outdoors

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's police commissioner has delivered an apology to First Nations people and pledged to "eliminate racism" within the force during a speech at Garma Festival.

title.children: 'I am deeply sorry': NT Police commissioner makes apology to Indigenous people at Garma

image.altText: A boxer in a blue outfit does a backflip in the ring.

props.synopsis: Charlie Senior will leave Paris with Australia's seventh Olympic boxing medal after upsetting Carlo Paalam on a split points decision in their quarterfinal.

title.children: Backflipping boxer Charlie Senior to land rare medal for Australia

image.altText: GettyImages-2164650041

props.synopsis: In emotional scenes, Imane Khelif wins her quarterfinal clash in the boxing to assure a medal at the Paris Olympics amid a cloud of misinformation and online trolling.

title.children: Algerian boxer Imane Khelif reduced to tears as she clinches Paris Olympics medal

image.altText: A street sign that reads 'Wall St' in foreground of USA flag

props.synopsis: There are genuine concerns the world's largest economy is heading toward a recession, and the fear is gripping global financial markets.

title.children: 'We are being tossed around on a sea of volatility': Fears US economy headed towards recession

image.altText: GettyImages-2164679482

props.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus pushes Katie Ledecky all the way in a classic 800m final, after Australia earlier secured more gold via the men's tennis doubles. Follow live.

title.children: Titmus claims 800m silver as American champ Ledecky adds to her Olympic legend

image.altText: A photo taken from over the top of the King and Queen showing off their crowns

props.synopsis: Days after he lost his job, the former assistant minister for a republic called the movement to offer reassurance.

title.children: The PM has torpedoed the republic portfolio, but the movement says it understands why

image.altText: A woman rides an e-scooter

props.synopsis: Some owners of private electric scooters in the Northern Territory are only just realising they are breaking the law by riding them in public places amid a push for legislation change.

title.children: Push for e-scooter reform in NT as owners learn using them in public places is illegal

props.synopsis: As more Australians opt in to share housing, photographer Aishah Kenton explores how the concept is changing from a home for now to a forever home.

title.children: The share house used to be home for a time. These roommates are changing that

image.altText: Police station shot up in flames

props.synopsis: Protesters attack police and start fires in Sunderland as violence spreads to another English city following a stabbing attack in Southport that left three children dead.

title.children: Protests turn violent in England as unrest spreads after Southport killings

image.altText: Bangladeshi activists point fingers at riot police amidst a scuffle during a protest.

props.synopsis: Student protesters in Bangladesh want an ingrained system of nepotism for some government jobs removed and replaced with a merit-based approach but their demonstrations have lead to fatal clashes with authorities — even for those only there to hand out water.

title.children: Students wanting better work opportunities in Bangladesh have instead been left injured or dead

image.altText: 3d rendering of abstract geometric shapes and cube blocks. Neon lights, blue and pink colors.

props.synopsis: Scientists are harnessing the Tetris effect, a phenomenon described by people who play the classic 1980s video puzzle game, to help unlock dreams and treat post traumatic stress disorder.

title.children: Love playing Tetris? Its effects on your brain are surprisingly profound

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: So you're back to give this quiz thing another go? Come on then, I promise I won't judge … much.

title.children: Still believe you can beat me at my own game? It's time to play … HARD!

image.altText: GettyImages-2164650418

props.synopsis: Matthew Ebden's Paris Olympics campaign started with a 6-0, 6-1 loss against Novak Djokovic, and ends with Australia's second-ever tennis gold medal alongside John Peers in the men's doubles.

title.children: Aussie doubles veterans come from behind to win gold in tense, triple-breaker final

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus

props.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus explains the pressure she felt coming into the Paris Olympics, as Australia added three more medals to its tally in the pool.

title.children: 'I felt so much pressure': Titmus opens up after claiming heroic 800m silver behind American legend

image.altText: Grae Morris flexes his muscles after winning windsurfing silver at the Paris Olympics.

props.synopsis: Australia's Grae Morris has won Olympic windsurfing silver, finishing behind Israel's Tom Reuveny in their lightning quick, three-sailor final in Marseille.

title.children: Grae Morris wins silver, Australia's first windsurfing medal in 32 years

image.altText: The British fantasy author Samantha Shannon, a woman in her early 30s with brunette hair and big eyes, smiling

props.synopsis: Samantha Shannon landed a six-figure publishing deal at the tender age of 20. Her first book, The Bone Season, was a huge hit. So why did she go and rewrite it?

title.children: Samantha's version: Why a bestselling British fantasy author is rewriting her old books

image.altText: A bowl of borscht soup, with some croutons on the saucer underneath.

props.synopsis: Borsch is the eastern European version of a vegetable soup. It's a convenient and delicious way of getting plenty of veggies, and this recipe from Alice Zaslavsky is a family favourite.

title.children: This easy vegetarian borsch is low on effort and big on flavour

image.altText: Players stand together and hold their medals and the Super Netball trophy as they smile for the camera

props.synopsis: The Thunderbirds are queens of Super Netball again, after beating the Vixens 59-57 in a grand final classic.

title.children: 'I had more to give': Thunderbirds win back-to-back titles after signing discarded veteran

image.altText: Two teenage girls lying on a bed with their hair draped over the side while looking at their phones.

props.synopsis: Teenage girls are the main accelerators of how language changes and evolves. It's a reminder that the most influential people in our society aren't always the most obvious.

title.children: The way teenage girls speak is often derided, but they are in fact our linguistic trailblazers

image.altText: A young man sitting in a wheelchair. Crutches lean against the wall.

props.synopsis: Martin had to buy a second-hand wheelchair held together with tape because the National Disability Insurance Scheme is only funding support for his autism, not his physical disabilities.

title.children: Martin can't access NDIS funding for his physical disabilities, so he bought a wheelchair second-hand

image.altText: A woman in Muslim headdress sitting opposite a man. Both are at a desk using laptops.

props.synopsis: The study's authors say more could be done by the federal government-funded eSafety Commissioner to make the internet a safer space.

title.children: Study of online hate finds Islamophobic and anti-Semitic comments are growing. Researchers say this has to change

image.altText: Eric Liddell poses in front of a stand wearing number 11 on his bib

props.synopsis: At the Paris Games of 1924, Scottish Presbyterian missionary and sprinter Eric Liddell completed one of the most romanticised feats in Olympic history. His is just one instance of athletes not competing on a Sunday.

title.children: Chariots of Fire, gentlemen's agreements, and a Bible-toting hurdler — how sport on the Sabbath has played a part in Olympics history

image.altText: Katie Ledecky leans back in the pool

props.synopsis: Katie Ledecky fourth-straight victory in the 800m has assured her Olympics immortality — but who is next in line to create greatness in the pool?

title.children: In achieving what only one other woman has ever done, Katie Ledecky has cemented her spot as an Olympics immortal

image.altText: Tilly Kearns shapes to shoot

props.synopsis: Here's everything that's going to happen on day nine of the Olympic Games.

title.children: Olympics schedule day nine: Aussie Stingers set to face off against Hungary in waterpolo

image.altText: Boat on ocean driving in the same area as a pod of dolphins

props.synopsis: Parks and wildlife rangers are investigating a commercial boat operator that tourists say they photographed motoring through a pod of dolphins on Queensland's Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Tourists accuse boat of driving through Noosa dolphin pod

image.altText: A black and white illustration of an island with water and a ship in the foreground.

props.synopsis: In 2008, six experienced walkers retraced the steps of cannibal convict Alexander Pearce almost two centuries on from the escape that earned him infamy. The hikers recently reunited to reflect on their 22-day journey through some of Tasmania's harshest country.

title.children: The gruelling walk inspired by a cannibal convict's daring escape almost 200 years earlier
